texts.shortText: Previously incorrectly called Bicellariella ciliata, which is a valid species, but is restricted to the North Atlantic. The local form was only recently recognised and described as a new, endemic species.

Colony white to pale pinkish and bushy, resembles a miniature willow tree with a naked branching ‘trunk’ giving rise to drooping ‘branches’ each made up of a double row of flaring zooecia.

Examined closely, the individual zooecia, which are less than 1 mm long, are oval and arranged alternately on either side of each branch. Each zooecium is elongate-oval with a large tear-drop shaped aperture and ends in 4-7 very long, curved, eye-lash-like spines. There is a single bird’s head avicularium at the base of each zooecium.
Individual zooecia less than 1 mm long, colonies typically about 6- 10 cm or more tall.

Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Lambert‘s Bay to Durban.
Fairly common on rocky substrata, especially under overhangs, on vertical faces and in caves to a depth of about 10 m. Little else know about biology.

All bryozoans are filter-feeders. The feeding zooids extend when undisturbed and the tentacles, which are lined with cilia, are expanded, forming a bell-shaped funnel. Beating of the cilia directs food particles down into the funnel and to the mouth, where they are ingested.
The colony is hermaphrodite, but individual zooids are male or female. Colonies expand by budding new zooecia at the tips. New colonies arise from sexual reproduction.

There a several other species with similar bushy, branching colony forms. The Spiral moss-animal Menipea triseriata occurs in the same locations, but its branches are spirally arranged and not curved downwards at their tips, and the zooecia also lack long spines. Menipea crispa is shorter with no trunk below the branches and has the branches curved downwards, each zooecium having only 2 long spines at its tip.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 138).

Day, JH (1969). A Guide to marine Life on South African Shores. AA Balkema, Cape Town. (p. 127 as B. ciliata).

Florence, WK, Hayward, PJ & Gibbons, MJ (2007). Taxonomy of shallow-water Bryozoa from the west coast of South Africa. African Natural History, 3(1), 1-58. (p. 21).
